title: Woman fled down street in underwear from abusive husband who threatened to hang her
text:

A woman was forced to flee down the street in her underwear after her abusive husband threatened to hang her.

The woman, who wants to remain anonymous, said she is still unable to get free from her sick ex as she has been unable to divorce him yet.

She said she has been left with PTSD after the monster raped her, spat tea at her face and hit her in the face with the bottle.

Detailing the horrific night he threatened to hang her, she told Wales Online : “He grabbed a rope and said ‘I will do this,’ I had the rope over my neck - I would pray he would take me away from this pain.

“All I can remember is that I passed out and wet myself with it.

“He then stopped what he was doing.

“I am petrified of this man, I thought he was going to kill me."

The woman from Swansea, south Wales, said on another occasion she was so terrified of him she bolted out the front door in her underwear.

She said: “I ran away one night, my neighbour saw me running away in my underwear.

(Image: Jonathan Myers/Wales Online)

“I was too afraid to answer the phone.

“The police found me and I only had my bra and knickers on."

The couple first met abroad in January, 2006, where the woman, who does not wish to be named following her horrendous ordeal, got to know him and his pal.

It was his friend she got on with best. But it was her eventual husband that she ended up with - despite her saying there was zero attraction.

Four weeks later the abuse began.

She said she went to the south coast of England at the end of the February to visit them both and he was jealous.

“He had a go at me after I went down to see both of them, I didn’t realise they both liked me,” she said.

“Within four weeks I did not recognise that the abuse had started. When I came back I was accused of sleeping with his friend."

He turned up in Swansea in April and again in May, she said.

(Image: Jonathan Myers/Wales Online)

"He came down and wanted to know what was going on and if I was in a relationship with his friend. I did not know how to get away.

"I wasn’t in a relationship with him - I didn’t want to get married.”

The warning signs were there, she said, but she stayed with him, even after he once grabbed the handbrake of her car as she drove along a Swansea road at 50mph.

“I fled from the car in tears, I thought he was going to kill me. But I refused to make a statement. Nothing was ever done.”

She added: “There were times when I went to leave and he snapped my car keys.”

But despite the constant abuse she said she felt forced into marrying him.

“I tried to end the relationship but he said he was not leaving, I was afraid.

“He gave up his job and one day told me ‘I will cause a scene in your workplace.’

“He said he wasn’t going back to England. He said, 'I am staying here now and we are going to get married' and we did."

They married in the summer of 2006.

Signs of domestic abuse Is your partner excessively jealous and possessive?

Is your partner charming one minute and abusive the next? Does your partner have sudden changes of mood – like Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde?

Is your partner stopping you from seeing your family and friends? Do you feel isolated?

Is your partner constantly criticizing you and putting you down in public?

Does your partner embarrass you, often in front of family and friends, so that you are seen in a bad light?

Does your partner play mind games and make you unsure of your own judgment?

Does your partner tell you you’re useless and couldn’t cope without them?

Does your partner control your money?

Does your partner tell you what to wear, who to see, where to go, what to think?

Does your partner pressure you to have sex when you don’t want to?

Are you starting to walk on eggshells to avoid making your partner angry?

Does your partner monitor your movements? Or check up on you via your email, Facebook, Twitter or by looking at your text messages?

Does your partner use anger and intimidation to frighten you and make you comply with his demands?

Has your partner ever threatened you, or intimidated you by using violent language or smashing up the furniture?

Are you forced to alter your behaviour because you are frightened of your partner’s reaction?

Are you blamed for their behaviour e.g. they say you were "asking for it" or deserved the abuse? If you answered yes to any of the above questions, then you may be experiencing domestic violence. Abuse is a crime and it is never your fault. You don’t have to deal with this alone. Call the freephone National Domestic Violence Helpline at any time on 0808 2000 247. Source: Refuge.org

“He got a temporary job in a factory.

“I found a flat for him to live in, he kept on saying: ‘We are getting married’.

“I was just so afraid, I was manipulated and so afraid.

“He accused me of taking medication from work.

“I have been accused of all sorts - I ended up marrying the wrong one.“

Other people started to notice there was something wrong in their relationship, she said, even at their wedding.

It was only the two of them and a couple of work colleagues, who acted as witnesses, at the registry office ceremony - she didn’t even tell her family about their big day.

“I was asked if I was okay on three occasions, I read the words in the vows back to the registrar - my daughter was not aware I was getting married and I didn’t tell her until two weeks later,” she said.

She said she later asked if she could annul her marriage, but was told ‘no’.

“I thought, I have made my bed and I have had to lay in it.”

It was far from wedded bliss, however, as she claimed the abuse only intensified when she tied the knot.

Between 2010 and 2014, the problems escalated which led to the NHS worker, now in her 50s, saying she was raped and suffering dozens of other incidents of abuse, including having food hurled over her.

“I got raped twice in 2011 and 2012. I was in quite a bad way after it happened,” she said.

“He hit me across the face with a bottle of wine just before Christmas because I came home late from work.

“I had blood across my face and a split lip.

“I have been slapped, pulled downstairs by my hair and he would spit tea over my face and he would throw food over my head.

“I have tried to leave him and he tried to pull the mirrors off my car.”

She said the problems escalated in 2010 and her partner was also cheating on her at that time.

She repeatedly tried to run away and said she would get on a plane to any part of the world that she could escape to.

“I thought this man was going to take my life,” she added.

“I would book a holiday and go away. I ran away to Australia, Vietnam and Cambodia on my own.

“I broke down in front of police officers."

But it wasn’t until 2012 that her husband faced some justice. He was convicted of assault in Swansea Magistrates Court, after pleading guilty.

But she was still unable to get out of the relationship.

In 2012 she said she desperately tried to leave, but it was not until 2015 that she finally did so.

She went on to discover how he had treated former partners as badly as her.

During her ordeal she said her weight plummeted to seven stone and she struggled to be able to live a normal everyday life, leading her boss to urge her to take time off work.

She said it was not the first relationship of domestic violence that she had endured and had faced a similar situation with the father of her daughter.

“My daughter’s dad was not a very nice person, I spent a lot of time in refuges I couldn’t do anything at all,” she said.

She said she was just grateful to have the support of the people she worked alongside. It was her colleagues that pulled her through.

“My colleagues would come to the doctors with me,” she said.

“I got myself out of a situation that I couldn’t get out of,” she added.

She now lives with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in the aftermath of years of domestic violence.

“I still get PTSD, I have been assessed by a psychiatrist.

“I told people I can feel his hands on me. I still get the tears, you do struggle.”

Her husband is barred from going near her, but she still looks over her shoulder in fear that he will again try to track her down.

She even asked her work to change her company car so he wouldn’t know the registration and she would be able to stay safe.

But she said he still had an element of control over her life, as she had so far been unable to divorce him.

However, she said she was determined to live every aspect of her life.

“I am not proud of what I have been through, I wished I was dead as I was constantly in fear of my life,” she said.

“I just embrace everything I can and that he did not break me.”
description: Swansea woman said she could remember the moment when he threw the rope around her neck as if it was yesterday, but she then “blacked out"
